Title: Water Dynamics in Gyroid Phases of Self-Assembled Gemini Surfactants
Authors: Santanu Roy, David Skoff, Dominic V. Perroni, Jagannath Mondal, Arun Yethiraj, Mahesh K. Mahanthappa, Martin T. Zanni, and James L. Skinner*
synopsis: Materials that can engage in selective ion transport, such as hydrated polymer membranes, can play a key role as components in solar cells and fuel cells. Though simulations have suggested that the surface roughness of their water-filled nanochannels significantly influence ion transport, the uncertain morphologies of these membranes have made it difficult to determine how the curvature of their pores influences water and ion motion. To investigate this question, Santanu Roy, James Skinner, and colleagues have used experiments and simulations to compare water motion in membranes with nanopores that have mostly convex or concave interfaces with water. Their results show that the convex surfaces have significantly less “curvature-induced frustration” than the concave surfaces, and thus move water and ions faster. The authors suggest that these findings could help guide the future design of artificial membranes that rapidly transport protons and other ions.

Title: Mimic of the Green Fluorescent Protein β-Barrel: Photophysics and Dynamics of Confined Chromophores Defined by a Rigid Porous Scaffold
Authors: Derek E. Williams, Ekaterina A. Dolgopolova, Perry J. Pellechia, Andrei Palukoshka, Thomas J. Wilson, Rui Tan, Josef M. Maier, Andrew B. Greytak, Mark D. Smith, Jeanette A. Krause, and Natalia B. Shustova*
synopsis: The properties of fluorescent chromophores often depend on their molecular conformation or environment. That is the case for green fluorescent protein (GFP), well known for its use as a gene expression reporter. The emission of GFP’s 4-hydroxybenzylidene imidazolinone fluorophore is largely controlled through interactions with a surrounding b-barrel protein. Natalia Shustova and colleagues have created a system to study GFP fluorescence by synthesizing a metal‒organic framework (MOF) as a mimic of the protein b-barrel. The researchers find that the maximum emission of their artificial framework is similar to the natural one and that the emission can be tuned by modifying the MOF. This work could lead to the design of new tunable fluorescent protein mimics.

Title: Giant Raman Response to the Encapsulation of Sulfur in Narrow Diameter Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes
Authors: Guanghui Li, Chengyin Fu, M. Belén Oviedo, Mingguang Chen, Xiaojuan Tian, Elena Bekyarova, Mikhail E. Itkis, Bryan M. Wong, Juchen Guo, and Robert C. Haddon*
synopsis: Lithium‒sulfur batteries have attracted attention in recent years as possible successors to lithium-ion batteries; sulfur’s high capacity as a cathode when paired with metallic elements such as lithium is advantageous in this regard. Some groups are exploring encapsulation of sulfur in single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) to improve cyclability or efficiency. Robert Haddon and colleagues report in a recent study that sulfur species encapsulated in narrow SWNTs show very large changes in Raman spectra, indicative of the sulfur’s interaction with the sidewalls of the SWNTs. This finding could change the way future lithium‒sulfur batteries are designed.

Title: How Does Confinement Change Ligand–Receptor Binding Equilibrium? Protein Binding in Nanopores and Nanochannels
Authors: Mario Tagliazucchi and Igal Szleifer*
synopsis: Studies on solid-state nanopores and nanochannels, notable for applications in chemical sensing and analysis, have largely focused on a strategy that involves monitoring changes in the conductance of a single pore as analytes pass through. Significantly less is known about a second strategy, in which an analyte, such as a protein, changes the nanochannel conductance by binding to specific ligands on the inner walls. In their study, Mario Tagliazucchi and Igal Szleifer explore factors at play in this second strategy. They find that using ligand molecules of the right length enables sensing of proteins that are much smaller than the radius of the channels. Moreover, the response of the sensor can be improved when the proteins and ligands have opposite charge. These results are fundamentally interesting, and they could guide the design and development of novel chemical sensors based on this second strategy.

Title: Rectified Proton Grotthuss Conduction Across a Long Water-Wire in the Test Nanotube of the Polytheonamide B Channel
Authors: Yuka Matsuki, Masayuki Iwamoto, Kenichiro Mita, Kenji Shigemi, Shigeki Matsunaga, and Shigetoshi Oiki*
synopsis: The process of proton transfer across membranes is important, as it forms the basis for designing biological proton channels and engineering fuel cell operations. Though the mechanism for protein transfer has been studied extensively, how protons permeate across passageways that embed a one-dimensional water chain is not well understood. Shigetoshi Oiki and colleagues explore this question in a new study using the natural peptide polytheonamide B, isolated from a marine sponge, as a model system for proton conduction. This proton channel is embedded within lipid bilayers in protic solutions. Electrical recordings show that protons move more rapidly in one direction through the channel than the other. The researchers attribute these results to the orientations of water molecules inside the proton-conducting channels. These findings could inform the design of targeted cytotoxic drugs or proton conductors in fuel cells.

Title: Base Flipping within the α-Hemolysin Latch Allows Single-Molecule Identification of Mismatches in DNA
Authors: Robert P. Johnson, Aaron M. Fleming, Laura R. Beuth, Cynthia J. Burrows*, and Henry S. White
synopsis: Mismatched base pairs are a relatively common error introduced by DNA polymerases during replication, but these mutations can be harmful if left unrepaired. The ability to identify the presence and position of these mistakes in DNA sequences will help researchers better understand how these errors occur, what effect they have on genomic fidelity, and how they are recognized and repaired. In a recent study, a team led by Cynthia Burrows and Henry White details a new method that uses the natural protein pore a-hemolysin to identify and differentiate DNA containing the mismatched base pairs CC and CA. Hemolysin forms a channel with a constricted “latch” at the top. The researchers show that as the mismatched base pairs pass through the latch, they cause a change in current recorded from this protein that is unique for each type of mismatch. The authors attribute the unique signals to the different mismatched bases jutting out from the DNA double strand and suggest that this technique could be expanded to identify signatures of other mismatch types.

Title: Bioinspired Protein Channel-Based Scanning Ion Conductance Microscopy (Bio-SICM) for Simultaneous Conductance and Specific Molecular Imaging
Authors: Florika C. Macazo and Ryan J. White*
synopsis: Nanopores have proven to be useful tools for sensitive and selective chemical sensing, with analytes causing a change in current through reversible binding or translocation. Though many studies have focused on synthetic nanopores, many naturally occurring protein channels can fulfill the same function. These biological nanopores can also be combined with other tools for added functionality. Florika Macazo and Ryan White demonstrate this capability by uniting the biological nanopore a-hemolysin and scanning ion conductance microscopy to yield a technique that gives information about surface topography. By integrating a protein channel into a lipid bilayer on a microscope probe tip, the researchers are able to simultaneously gather information about the presence of b-cyclodextrin molecules on a substrate and their subsequent migration into the probe. The authors suggest that this blended tool could provide combined spatial, chemical, and mechanistic information on molecular transport processes.

Title: Electrochemical Tip-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy
Authors: Zhi-Cong Zeng, Sheng-Chao Huang, De-Yin Wu, Ling-Yan Meng, Mao-Hua Li, Teng-Xiang Huang, Jin-Hui Zhong, Xiang Wang, Zhi-Lin Yang, and Bin Ren*
synopsis: Raman spectroscopy can obtain the molecular fingerprint information of surface and interface at a nanoscale resolution using nanospectroscopies like tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS). However, nanospectroscopies are not as useful in electrochemical systems, where interfacial structures can change with electrode potentials. Bin Ren and colleagues detail a new technique known as electrochemical TERS (EC-TERS) that can produce clear chemical information of adsorbates under changing potentials using a modified scanning tunneling microscope (STM). A key to EC-TERS is introducing light at a 10° angle, which minimizes optical distortion in the small stage of a STM. Understanding of nanoscale confined reactions in electrochemical systems including solar cells, lithium ion batteries, and fuel cells could be improved through applications of this new technique.

Title: Reactions in Elastomeric Nanoreactors Reveal the Role of Force on the Kinetics of the Huisgen Reaction on Surfaces
Authors: Xu Han, Shudan Bian, Yong Liang, K. N. Houk, and Adam B. Braunschweig*
synopsis: Researchers still know very little about the role of mechanical force in bond formation. To explore this topic, Adam Braunschweig and colleagues test the effects of mechanical pressure on a Huisgen-type cycloaddition “click” reaction that joins alkynes and azides together. The researchers coat an array of elastomeric tips mounted onto an atomic force microscope with alkynes and then press these onto a layer of azides adhered on a substrate, using different amounts of force to initiate the reaction. Their results show that the amount of pressure is a critical factor governing the reaction rate, and this understanding may translate to advances in materials science, biology, and nanotechnology.

Title: Tip-Directed Synthesis of Multimetallic Nanoparticles
Authors: Peng-Cheng Chen, Guoliang Liu, Yu Zhou, Keith A. Brown, Natalia Chernyak, James L. Hedrick, Shu He, Zhuang Xie, Qing-Yuan Lin, Vinayak P. Dravid, Stacy A. O’Neill-Slawecki, and Chad A. Mirkin*
synopsis: Alloy nanoparticles, composed of two or more metals, have potential for applications in fields including catalysis, plasmonics, electronics, and magnetics. Even though these materials are often synthesized in solution, most applications require alloy nanoparticles to be integrated into specific sites on substrates. Toward that goal, Chad Mirkin and colleagues have developed a method, known as scanning probe block copolymer lithography (SPBCL), to synthesize single alloy nanoparticles on surfaces using polymer inks with incorporated metals as precursors. With this technique, they are able to synthesize nanoparticles composed of mixtures of gold, silver, palladium, nickel, cobalt, and platinum and demonstrate their enhanced catalytic activity. The work showcases the potential for this technique in creating new and potentially useful nanostructured catalysts and catalyst libraries.

Title: Redox Cycling on Recessed Ring-Disk Nanoelectrode Arrays in the Absence of Supporting Electrolyte
Authors: Chaoxiong Ma, Nicholas M. Contento, and Paul W. Bohn*
synopsis: Typical electrochemical experiments require a high concentration of background electrolyte, which carries the vast majority of the current between electrodes. Paul Bohn and colleagues buck this trend in a recent study, showing that large current enhancements are possible with no supporting electrolyte in a recessed ring-disk nanoelectrode array. Using the redox species Ru(NH3)62+/3+, the researchers show that at low analyte concentrations and without the supporting electrolyte, ions accumulate in the array’s nanopores, leading to significantly increased current amplification compared to redox cycling with the supporting electrolyte present. Ion enrichment and ion migration effects act in synergy with redox cycling in this system, leading to a total current amplification up to 2000-fold compared to a single microelectrode array of the same area. The authors note that this phenomenon makes these unusual arrays a useful tool for electrochemical processing and analysis.

Title: Self-Supported PdxBi Catalysts for the Electrooxidation of Glycerol in Alkaline Media
Authors: Anna Zalineeva, Alexey Serov, Monica Padilla, Ulises Martinez, Kateryna Artyushkova, Stève Baranton, Christophe Coutanceau*, and Plamen B. Atanassov
synopsis: Direct alcohol fuel cells (DAFCs) have recently attracted interest as a possible alternative to hydrogen-fed fuel cells, with glycerol proposed as a convenient, biorenewable fuel. However, for the maximum energy conversion from glycerol, it must be completely oxidized into carbon dioxide through the breaking of carbon–carbon bonds, a feat that has proven difficult at DAFCs’ low working temperatures. Christophe Coutanceau, Plamen Atanassov, and colleagues report a way around this problem using porous catalysts made of palladium and bismuth. Reactants and intermediates collect in these pores, making carbon–carbon bonds to vulnerable to electrooxidation at high potentials. This work demonstrates an important step toward the use of glycerol in DAFCs.

Title: Toward Fundamentals of Confined Catalysis in Carbon Nanotubes
Authors: Jianping Xiao, Xiulian Pan*, Shujing Guo, Pengju Ren, and Xinhe Bao
synopsis: (Using Carbon Nanotubes for Tuning Catalytic Activity – Alexander Hellemans) Researchers led by Xiulian Pan and Xinhe Bao have studied the mechanisms underlying the effect of carbon nanotube (CNT) encapsulation on the reduced or enhanced catalytic activity for a number of transition metal catalysts. Combining density functional theory with previously reported experimental results for several CNT-encapsulated transition metal catalysts, they find that the nanospace and π electrons—highly mobile electrons present in the curved graphene sheets that make up nanotubes—affect the dissociative binding energy of several probe molecules. It is decreased on the encapsulated particles with respect to those outside of the nanotube. For encapsulated iron, the weakened binding results in an increased catalytic activity in carbon monoxide hydrogenation, while for ruthenium the confinement results in the opposite effect in carbon monoxide hydrogenation and ammonia decomposition. Nanotubes and the confinement effects may be used to modulate important catalytic processes.

Title: Lab-in-a-Shell: Encapsulating Metal Clusters for Size Sieving Catalysis
Authors: Zhen-An Qiao, Pengfei Zhang*, Song-Hai Chai, Miaofang Chi, Gabriel M. Veith, Nidia C. Gallego, Michelle Kidder, and Sheng Dai*
synopsis: Metal catalysts are vital for a variety of applications, including petroleum refining, fine chemical production, and environmental remediation. However, catalytic nanoparticles tend to grow, aggregate, or detach from their supports during use, reducing catalytic activity. Though encapsulating metal particles inside porous shells could solve this problem, creating structures with efficient yield and activity has been a challenge. Zhen-An Qiao, Pengfei Zhang, Sheng Dai, and colleagues report a new way to create such core‒shell catalysts using hollow silica nanospheres as miniature laboratories in which to grow metal clusters. The resulting structures are unexpectedly able to act as molecular sieves, promoting oxidation only in molecules of a certain size. This work could open new avenues for synthesizing core‒shell nanomaterials, especially those useful in catalytic applications.

Title: Hollow Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework Nanospheres as Highly Efficient Cooperative Catalysts for [3+3] Cycloaddition Reactions
Authors: Fang Zhang, Yongyi Wei, Xiaotao Wu, Huangyong Jiang, Wei Wang*, and Hexing Li
synopsis: Enzymes are nature’s ideal catalysts, and they possess a wide array of useful features—they not only can lower a reaction’s activation energy but also can selectively bind a substrate of the appropriate size in the correct position for optimal activation and reactivity, and preferentially bind substrates over products. Developing a synthetic catalyst that possesses these features has proven to be an enormous design challenge. Wei Wang, Hexing Li, and colleagues move closer to that goal by reporting a new catalyst for [3+3] cycloaddition reactions. The team’s catalyst is made of a zeolitic imidazolate framework, a metal‒organic framework of zinc ion nodes linked by imidazole struts. The acidic zinc and basic imidazole act synergistically to bring the two substrates into proximity and activate them cooperatively, while the flexible shell on these nanospheres accommodates substrates of different sizes. The authors suggest that this strategy could be useful for catalyzing a range of different chemical reactions.

Title: Controlling Structure and Porosity in Catalytic Nanoparticle Superlattices with DNA
Authors: Evelyn Auyeung, William Morris, Joseph E. Mondloch, Joseph T. Hupp, Omar K. Farha, and Chad A. Mirkin*
synopsis: In recent years, researchers have taken advantage of DNA-mediated assembly to design and build highly tunable nanoparticle superlattices, which can be utilized as functional materials in optics, plasmonics, electronics, catalysis, and beyond. However, in some of these applications superlattice solubility as well as the presence of the DNA linkers is a concern. In their study, Chad Mirkin and colleagues detail a method for employing gold nanoparticle-based superlattices in catalytic reactions by embedding them in silica and then calcinating them. This process removes the DNA, leaving behind supported, porous nanoparticle superlattices that are able to catalyze alcohol oxidation. This method offers an attractive way to create new catalytic superlattices with customized nanoparticle size, composition, and interparticle spacing.

Title: Recyclable Catalytic Dendrimer Nanoreactor for Part-Per-Million Cu<sup>I</sup> Catalysis of “Click” Chemistry in Water
Authors: Christophe Deraedt, Noël Pinaud, and Didier Astruc*
synopsis: “Click” chemistry reactions that join together azides and alkynes are typically catalyzed by copper ions, and a non-trivial amount of this toxic metal is left behind after a reaction. This residual impurity has prevented the use of this type of reaction in electronics and biomedicine. Seeking a new way, Didier Astruc and colleagues have synthesized branched molecules that form a capsule to act as a contained nanoreactor, dramatically reducing the amount of catalyst necessary to just a few parts per million. These dendrimer nanoreactors not only successfully house the desired chemical reaction, which does not take place in their absence, but also can be recycled and used multiple times. The authors note that, with the significantly lower amount of copper catalysis needed, these nanoreactors could be useful for the mass production of biomedical or cosmetic products.

Title: Modulation of Reactivity in the Cavity of Liposomes Promotes the Formation of Peptide Bonds
Authors: Anna Grochmal, Luba Prout, Robert Makin-Taylor, Rafel Prohens, and Salvador Tomas*
synopsis: In cells, lipid membrane-bound compartments may affect intracellular reactions in various ways, for example by increasing the effective concentrations of reactants, thereby speeding up reactions, or by inhibiting or slowing reactions by segregating reactants. However, many other effects are obscured by the complex regulatory mechanisms typical of biomolecular systems. To better understand the role that these membrane-bound compartments play in a simpler system, Salvador Tomas and colleagues study how peptide bonds form within minimal lipid vesicles. Using two modified amino acids, one membrane-impermeable and one membrane-permeable, the researchers find that the interior of the vesicle provides an environment that promotes dipeptide formation, whereas the exterior environment causes degradation of one of the amino acids. The authors suggest that these findings could help explain the origins of life as well as inform the design of artificial cells.

Title: Supracrystalline Colloidal Eggs: Epitaxial Growth and Freestanding Three-Dimensional Supracrystals in Nanoscaled Colloidosomes
Authors: Zhijie Yang, Thomas Altantzis, Daniele Zanaga, Sara Bals, Gustaaf Van Tendeloo, and Marie-Paule Pileni*
synopsis: Chemical reactions confined by templates enable the formation of complex molecules that would be difficult to produce in other ways. Though researchers first used this method more than 20 years ago to synthesize nanocrystals, applying it to nanocrystal assembly from colloids has been less successful due to a lack of suitable templates as well as poor control over their assembly in a confined space. Marie-Paule Pileni and colleagues report a new method that produces not only single-layer nanocrystal assemblies but also three-dimensional “supracrystals” of one or multiple types of nanocrystals. The team forms nanocrystal colloidosomes, hollow balls of nanocrystals, and then uses these as nanoreactors in which to grow other nanocrystals. These colloidal assemblies could have applications in biomedicine, for example as drug delivery agents, imaging tools, hyperthermia therapeutics, and more.

Title: Poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-tris-nitrilotriacetic acid acrylamide) for a Combined Study of Molecular Recognition and Spatial Constraints in Protein Binding and Interactions
Authors: Juan Liu, Mariana Spulber, Dalin Wu, Renee M. Talom, Cornelia G. Palivan*, and Wolfgang Meier
synopsis: Most biological processes depend on precise molecular recognition and spatial constraints between different molecules. Though interactions between different molecules such as proteins can be successfully predicted using computer simulations, there are few accurate models to investigate the influence of spatial constraints on binding and activity. In their study, Cornelia Palivan, Wolfgang Meier, and colleagues detail a new way to simultaneously investigate both molecular recognition and spatial constraints using a library of polymers. Each polymer has multiple sites that bind to histidine tags, spaced apart at various distances. This system reveals that small molecular mass molecules can bind to sites on any of the polymers, yet large molecules such as proteins only bind to polymers where the average distance between histidine tag binding sites is larger than the proteins themselves. This system could eventually be used to organize proteins or other molecules for combination therapies.
